title: El Chapo's family works to build new university in his hometown city
text:
El Chapo's family is planning to build a university in the town where the jailed drug kingpin was born.

The school will be constructed in Badiraguato, Mexico, and is one of three projects the family is looking to launch with Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán's cash that has been seized by the United States. They will also seek financial assistance from the Mexican government.

Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador and El Chapo's mother Maria Consuelo Loera are expected to perform the groundbreaking ceremony.

'We are hoping that when President López Obrador makes his first visit to Sinaloa he will go to Badiraguato and lay the stone together with El Chapo's mother, María Consuelo, and work can finally begin on building the university,' family attorney, José Luis González Meza, said Friday.

The family of Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán (pictured) announced they will construct the first indigenous university in Badiraguato, Mexico, the jailed drug lord's hometown

Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador and El Chapo's mother Maria Consuelo Loera (seen above) are expected to perform the groundbreaking ceremony

El Chapo's family has tapped Mexican painter Hugo Zúñiga de Guerrero for the ambitious project.

González Meza did not reveal the cost of the university.

Another project will involve the family overseeing the revival of a chain of affordable food markets that will sell meals at 50 percent below cost.

The stores will sell cheap food, coffee, tequila, beer and mezcal.

Similar stores had existed during the days Joaquín Hernández Galicia ruled over the powerful oil workers union.

El Chapo's family want the Mexican government to finance the project through two trusts allegedly left behind by Hernández Galicia.

He died in 2013 after spending nine years in prison after troops stormed his home and arrested him on manslaughter and weapons charges in 1989 in what the government described as a crackdown on corruption.

The last plan will develop a pharmaceutical industry which will provide affordable medicine to Mexico before expanding its service throughout Central America.

González Meza claims the family is wanting to 'provide low-cost food and medicine for Mexicans' and is not concerned with making money for themselves.

Both the association and pharmaceutical company will be headed by farmers and indigenous people.

'They will be the future industrialists of this country,' González Meza said.

El Chapo's family is also looking into creating a pharmaceutical company that will provide affordable medicine to lower-income Mexicans families and in the future hopes to provide the same service throughout Central America. Pictured is Maria Consuelo Loera, the mother of Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán

Mexico is seeking to have assets confiscated by the United States be returned to El Chapo's (center) home country because they belong to the people

El Chapo is currently serving a life sentence at a super maximum security facility in Florence, Colorado, where he is kept isolated for 23 hours a day.

United States prosecutors estimated the co-founder of the Sinaloa Cartel generated generated at least $11.8 billion in cocaine, $846 million in marijuana and $11 million in heroin.

The U.S. government demanded El Chapo pay back $12.6 billion that he made off drug sales during his 25 years at the helm of the international criminal enterprise.

López Obrador argued in July that assets confiscated by the United States be returned to El Chapo's home country of Mexico.

'I think that everything that is confiscated and that has to do with Mexico has to be returned to the Mexicans,' the Mexican leader said.
description: Joaquín 'El Chapo' Guzmán's family revealed they will construct the first indigenous university in Badiraguato, Mexico, the birthplace of the jailed drug kingpin.
